title.narrative: Building a stable and peaceful Africa

description.narrative: Horn of Africa, North Africa and Sahel including the Lake Chad Basin region
Strengthening continental criminal justice and rule of law responses

To enhance knowledge, and improve policy and practice on the rule of law, governance and peacebuilding.
Outcome 1: Enhanced research-based knowledge on threats to governance, rule of law and peace building in Africa, and how best to respond
Outcome 2: Improved national, regional and continental strategy, policy and practice on governance, rule of law and peace building
Outcome 3: Strengthened donor programming in response to governance, rule of law and peacebuilding challenges in Africa

title.narrative: Workshop on the Future of Algeria

description.narrative: AFI held workshops held on the future of Algeria with country issue area experts, goverment and development agencies. Feedback from participants on the evaluation sheets were very positive and we got data and networks for more consultative events in the future.

title.narrative: Strengthening criminal justice and rule of law responses: Seminar on Community Resilience to Violent Extremism and Dialogue in Kenya and Uganda

description.narrative: CTAP launched the findings of studies in Kenya and Uganda related to community resilience to violent extremism and opportunities for dialogue within communities and between security/justice actors and VE groups.

title.narrative: Participants for the launches in Nairobi and Kampala included state representatives charged with implementation of P/CVE National and County Action Plans.

description.narrative: The launch of the study report and findings was a unnique hybrid model - both virtual and physical for participants in Nairobi and Kampala, while respecting COVID-19 regulations in Kenya and Uganda respectively. The discussions were particularly rich and indicated a continued need to develop these two aspects on P/CVE processes in both countries.

comment.narrative: Common understanding among policy makers in Kenya and Uganda on dialogue and community resilience in P/CVE processes
56 participants drawn from government and non-governmental organisations participated in the hybrid events in Nairobi and Kampala.

title.narrative: Strengthening criminal justice and rule of law responses: Seminar on Land, reparations and transitional justice in South Sudan (Juba, Torit, Wau, Yambio and Yei) on land and reparations in the transitionaljustice agenda in South Sudan

description.narrative: CTAP launched the findings of studies in South Sudan (Juba, Torit, Wau, Yambio and Yei) related to a study that links the land situation and reparations to the transitional justice process and revitalised peace agreement for South Sudan.

title.narrative: Participants in Juba included state representatives charged with implementation of land matters, National Human Rights Commission and CSOs.

description.narrative: The launch of the study report and findings was a unnique hybrid model - both virtual and physical for participants in Juba, while respecting COVID-19 regulations in South Sudan. The discussions were particularly rich and indicated a continued need to support and advocate for transitional justice processes in South Sudan.

comment.narrative: Common understanding among policy makers in South Sudan on transtional justice processes
47 participants attended the hybrid event at the Pyramid Hotel, Juba

The first was a discussion at the offices of the Hanns Seidel Foundation followed by a round-table discussion and a working breakfast meeting at the Fürstensalon, Bayerischer Hof, on the margins of the Munich Security Conference.

title.narrative: contributions made to enhance evidence based knowledge and undersatnding on the human secrity challenges facing the Sahel

description.narrative: Number of contributions made to enhance evidence based knowledge and undersatnding on the human secrity challenges facing the Sahel Instruction: This indicator is rated at the beginning and at the end of the project to calculate the project performance

baseline.value: Need of evidence-based timely analysis on the socio-economic and political dynamics governance stabilization and social cohesion challenges these countries face against the backdrop of an expanding terrorist threat and in some contexts approaching electoral competition or recent leadership change.

comment.narrative: Evidence-based timely analysis on the socio-economic and political dynamics, governance, stabilization and social cohesion challenges these countries face against the backdrop of an expanding terrorist threat and in some contexts, approaching electoral competition or recent leadership change to support policy and feed directly into decision making processes.
Number of contributions made to enhance evidence based knowledge and undersatnding on the human secrity challenges facing the Sahel

1) The ISS conducted pre-election 2 consultative missions in Burkina and Niger, where the team met representatives of political parties, government institutions, civil society organisations, international partners, as well as researchers, and other relevant actors. 2) The team also monitored the broader societal and socio economic developments in the Sahel. The data and information gathered and analysed through this work led to the publication of analytical pieces, presentations, briefings and interviews. 3) The ISS conducted two additional field missions. The first one in the region of Kayes in Mali, looking at the human security challenges linked to the gold economy in the region. The second one in Niger, aimed at providing support to the High authority for consolidation of peace in the organization of a seminar on stabilization and the fight against insurgent terrorism. This was also the occasion to conduct interviews in the framework of the project looking at the security dynamics in the region of Maradi and and team also provided technical support to the West Africa Network for Peacebuilding (WANEP).
Number of contributions made to enhance evidence based knowledge and undersatnding on the human secrity challenges facing the Sahel

The ISS conducted pre-election 2 consultative missions in Burkina and Niger, where the team met representatives of political parties, government institutions, civil society organisations, international partners, as well as researchers, and other relevant actors. The team also monitored the broader societal and socio economic developments in the Sahel. The data and information gathered and analysed through this work led to the publication of 4 analytical pieces, 14 presentations, 10 briefings and 19 interviews.

description.narrative: These are direct research outputs (comprising: publications, policy breifings, media interviews, an expert contributions to ISS and external events) delivered on issues related to peace agreements

comment.narrative: By the end of 2021, ISS intends to have delivered at least 6 research outputs informed by the findings of the research and analytical work on the issue of dialogue with VE Groups in the Sahel. These outputs may include any combination of publications, policy briefings, media interviews and expert contributions to ISS and external events addressing the issue of dialogue with VE groups at national or local level.
At the request of the Dutch embassy in Mali, ISS delivered a briefing on dialogue and negotiation with non-state armed actors in Mali on 17 November.

By the end of 2021, ISS intends to have delivered at least 6 research outputs informed by the findings of the research and analytical work on the issue of dialogue with VE Groups in the Sahel. These outputs may include any combination of publications, policy briefings, media interviews and expert contributions to ISS and external events addressing the issue of dialogue with VE groups at national or local level.

ISS West Africa Report (WAR) on VE in the Lake Chad Bassin published in march 2021, covers this issue. ISS also did an interview the 10th of june with the Journal du Mali in which it explained why France opposes to a dialogue with VE groups.

By the end of 2021, ISS intends to have delivered at least 6 research outputs informed by the findings of the research and analytical work on the issue of dialogue with VE Groups in the Sahel. These outputs may include any combination of publications, policy briefings, media interviews and expert contributions to ISS and external events addressing the issue of dialogue with VE groups at national or local level.

On Friday the 12th of August, ISS had a morning briefing on the possible ways to curb insecurity in Mali through dialogue and negotiations with non-state armed actors. On the 16th of September, ISS delivered to UK FCDO a briefing on dialogue with VEOs in the Sahel.

title.narrative: Enhancing security and governance challenges in the Horn of Africa - Provided key support to international organisations and partners in their effort to stability in the Horn of Africa region through production of knowledge

description.narrative: The Intergovernmental Authority on Development (IGAD) Agriculture & Environment Division invited the Horn program for its inception meeting on IGAD blue economy project to share knowledge on the implementation of its project on enhancing blue economy on the IGAD coastal member states for biodiversity conservation and livelihood diversification and to identify further potential synergies or collaborations in October 2021. The Horn program was also invited as a panellist to IGAD for Pease: Shaping peace together webinar organized by the IGAD Secretariat for the 21 September International Peace Day on Sep 20, 2021 to contribute to the discourse. UNDP reached out to the Horn program to be the only bidder to develop a state of governance, peace and security report for the Horn of Africa that helps with the assessment of the implementation of its Comprehensive Regional Prevention Strategy for the Horn.

comment.narrative: 1) Briefing to ECOWAS mission on the political situation in Mali, 16 July 2020 - At the request of the ECOWAS Office in Mali, ISS briefed the delegation of ECOWAS mediation mission on the resolution of the socio-political crisis in Mali. The briefing provided an opportunity to convey some key messages on the situation, particularly the urgency of laying out the foundations for a political process that would facilitate an irreversible implementation of essential governance reforms and forestall another episode of uncertainty in Mali and the region. 2) At the request of the Ministry of foreign Affairs of the Netherlands, the ISS organized a briefing on the ongoing political crisis in Mali. This briefing focused on the causes of military interference on the political scene, the intentions and reactions of the various national and international actors. Discussions also focused on the impact of these events on the security situation in the country and the region on 2 september and follow up on 15 september. 3) Briefing to Embassy of Belgium. Economic and political officer on 2 september on Situation in the Sahel. 5) Briefing to Dutch MFA on 9 september on Spillover of violent extremism to West African coastal states. 6) Briefing to Dutch foreign affairs officer in charge of stabilisation on 28 september on update of the situation. 7) Briefing to EU and EU member states political advisors from embassies in Dakar on situation in Mali on 29 september. 8) Briefing to OSIWA, Governance Unit Programme Head, 20 july, on Ongoing crisis in Mali. 9) Briefing to Members of the EU Sahel team, 23 july on Role of the EU in the Malian crisis after the ECOWAS mediation. 10) On Coup d'état in Mali to UNOWAS Sahel Team on 20 august.

1) Briefing to the delegation of Ireland on the security and socio-economic situation in the Sahel. 2) Briefing to West African Economic and Monetary Union peace and security delegate on the current secrity dynamics in the Liptako-Gourmal. 3) Briefing to representative of the University of Edinburghon C19 and peace processes in the case of Mali. 4) Several briefings on the Covid-19 situation in West Africa and the Sahel to : the World Food Program, the UK Conflict, Security and Stability Fund

Number of non-security accompanying measures and development interventions

1) Technical support to the Mauritania presidency of the G5 Sahel, the ISS was invited by the current Mauritania presidency of the G5 Sahel, to provide technical support for the organization a fourth conference on strengthening relations between defence and security forces and local populations in the G5 Sahel states. This conference is scheduled on 26 January 2021. The invitation by the host government provides opportunities to enhance the policy impact of analysis generated across ongoing research streams. 2)Upon request from the G5 Sahel Executive Secretariat, the ISS drafted a proposal for the organisation of an international Symposium on the current state and strategic priorities of policy-relevant research on violent extremism and radicalization in the G5 Sahel countries. The Symposium is expected to be implemented in partnership with USAID/ P for Peace. Following initial feedback from P4P in August, the Sahel team submitted a revised version of this proposal in September for a 6-month project. P4P update in November revealed that the proposal was still under review. Should the project be confirmed, an updated start date will be determined in 2021.

comment.narrative: Number of non-security accompanying measures and development interventions

1) Technical support to the Mauritania presidency of the G5 Sahel, the ISS was invited by the current Mauritania presidency of the G5 Sahel, to provide technical support for the organization a fourth conference on strengthening relations between defence and security forces and local populations in the G5 Sahel states. This conference is scheduled on 26 January 2021. The invitation by the host government provides opportunities to enhance the policy impact of analysis generated across ongoing research streams. 2)Upon request from the G5 Sahel Executive Secretariat, the ISS drafted a proposal for the organisation of an international Symposium on the current state and strategic priorities of policy-relevant research on violent extremism and radicalization in the G5 Sahel countries. The Symposium is expected to be implemented in partnership with USAID/ P for Peace. Following initial feedback from P4P in August, the Sahel team submitted a revised version of this proposal in September for a 6-month project. P4P update in November revealed that the proposal was still under review. Should the project be confirmed, an updated start date will be determined in 2021. 3) Publication of a report (French version) on 29 March 2021: Responding to insecurity in the Liptako-Gourma - Many initiatives have been launched in recent years to address the growing instability in the Liptako-Gourma region. This report analyses some of the measures adopted by states to stabilise this region. It is based on interviews carried out in Burkina Faso, Mali and Niger with actors responsible for designing or implementing these responses and with interlocutors from areas affected by insecurity.

Instruction: This indicator is rated at the beginning and the end of the project to identify the new non-security accompanying measures

comment.narrative: Number of non-security accompanying measures and development interventions

Technical support to the rotating presidencies of Niger, Burkina and Mauritania for the G5 Sahel o organise 2nd, 3rd and 4th annual Conference on strengthening relations between defence and security forces and local populations in the G5 Sahel states. The invitation by the host government provides opportunities to enhance the policy impact of analysis generated across ongoing research streams. Moreover, upon request from the G5 Sahel Executive Secretariat, the ISS drafted a proposal for the organisation of an international Symposium on the current state and strategic priorities of policy-relevant research on violent extremism and radicalization in the G5 Sahel countries. The Symposium is expected to be implemented in partnership with USAID/ P for Peace. Following initial feedback from P4P in August, the Sahel team submitted a revised version of this proposal in September for a 6-month project. P4P update in November revealed that the proposal was still under review. Should the project be confirmed, an updated start date will be determined in 2021. 3) Publication of a report (French version) on 29 March 2021: Responding to insecurity in the Liptako-Gourma - Many initiatives have been launched in recent years to address the growing instability in the Liptako-Gourma region. This report analyses some of the measures adopted by states to stabilise this region. It is based on interviews carried out in Burkina Faso, Mali and Niger with actors responsible for designing or implementing these responses and with interlocutors from areas affected by insecurity.

1) The G5 Sahel Executive Secretariat requested technical support from the ISS in organising a regional symposium on research into radicalization and violent extremism in the Sahel and West Africa. The Symposium seeks to create a framework for exchange between research centers and P/CVE practitioners. This should lead to the elaboration of a strategic research agenda for the G5 Sahel and other decision-makers in the G5 Sahel countries for the prevention of radicalization and violent extremism. The symposium originally planned for June has been postponed to november 2020 because of the Covid-19 pandemic.
Number of non-security accompanying measures and development interventions

1) The G5 Sahel has requested support from the ISS in the organisation of an upcoming regional symposium on the theme: "State of the art in the Prevention of radicalization and Violent Extremism (PREV) in the Sahel" in partnership with USAID P4P. The overall objective is to rely on Strategic Research on violent extremism and radicalization in West Africa and the Sahel to better understand the phenomenon and effectively grasp the means and methods to eradicate it. - Upcoming
Number of non-security accompanying measures and development interventions

title.narrative: Number of seminars, conferences or workshops to which the project contributed

description.narrative: Number of seminars, conferences or workshops to which the project contributed

comment.narrative: 1) At the invitation of the Global Public Policy Institute (GPPI), the team participated in a virtual workshop on the theme: COVID-19: An Opportunity for a Reset in the Sahel Region? on 20 August. The team presented its initial analysis of how COVID-19 has exposed governance challenges in the Sahel, albeit not directly leading to major upheavals in the region . 2) At the invitation of the gold mining company IAMGOLD, the team presented analysis of the risks posed by upcoming elections in Burkina Faso and Côte d’Ivoire and the implications a deteriorating political and security situation could have on its operations on 27 August. This request shows the increasing interest for ISS research by the private sector. 3) The team was invited by the laboratory of analysis of societies and power (Laboratoire d’analyses des sociétés et pouvoirs LASPAD) of the University Gaston Berger of Senegal to a discussion on the Mali coup and future perspectives. 4) On 3 September, the ISS was invited by the CGIAR to participate as a panelist in a webinar on climate security in the Sahel. The ISS shared insights and analysis on the drivers of conflict in the Sahel and how climate-smart interventions can help to alleviate some of the root causes of conflicts in the region. Recordings of the webinar were later turned into a Global Dispatches audio podcast. 5) On 23 September, the ISS was invited by the Danish Refugee Council (DRC) and the Danish Network for Conflict Prevention and Peacebuilding to share its insights and analysis in a panel discussion on the impact of measures taken to prevent/mitigate the spread of COVID-19 on conflict dynamics and displacement trends, and changes in the structures, incentives and conditions for peace. 6) On 30 September, ISS was invited by the Konrad Adenauer Stiftung (KAS) in Brussels to participate in a closed webinar for EU policy makers on the Sahel. The webinar focused on issues of coordination and trust-building in the region, and against the specific backdrop of Mali’s current crisis.

1) Presentation of ISS data to the students-Officers of the 2nd promotion of the G5 Sahel Defence College, Nouakchott, 24-25 February 2020 2) Briefing to United Nations Development Program (UNDP) during its meeting for the Sahel Support Plan of the UN Integrated Strategy for the Sahel (UNISS), Dakar, 22 January 2020 3) Presentation on violent extremism, organised crime and local conflicts in the Liptako-Gourma region at the Accra Initiative ministerial meeting, Bamako, 14 January 2020 4) Invitation to participate in the Public Roundtable on the Prevention of Violent Extremism, Geneva, 30 January 2020 5) Invitation to make a presentation on the evolution of the insecurity in the Sahel, highlighting risks for coastal states and to share analytical perspectives on key security challenges in West-Africa at the UNOWAS bi-annual office retreat, Dakar, 30 January 2020 6) 2nd meeting of the Governors of the Liptako-Gourma Border Regions, Bamako, 10-12 March 7) ECOWAS and the United Nations Office for West Africa and the Sahel (UNOWAS) workshop on transhumance, Abuja, 10-11 February 2020 8) Presentation of ISS data to the students-Officers of the 2nd promotion of the G5 Sahel Defence College, Nouakchott, 24-25 February 2020

Due to the Covid-19 pandemic, several events have been cancelled or postponed. The team has nonetheless contributed to a few online seminars. 1) Invitation to present by the Open Society European Policy Institute in a webinar to assess and discuss European approaches to the Sahel. As European decision-makers re-examine their strategy in an increasingly prominent region in the EU’s foreign policy outlook, the discussion focused on improving the EU’s security engagement and its implications for longer-term governance and development in the Sahel, Bamako (online event), 19 May 2020 2) The ISS was invited by the International Peace Institute (IPI), the Stimson Center, and Security Council Report (SCR), which aims to support the sustained engagement of member states in broader discussions on making UN peace operations better fit for purpose. The presentation stressed the fact that the multiplicity and interdependence of the armed forces operating in the Sahel implies the need for a common ethics in action. The blunders committed by the national armies or a coalition of armies can have an impact on the efforts to stabilize the country. These abuses stir up disagreements between the SDF and certain communities and contribute to further weakening their relations with the state.

1) The briefing to the Deputy Commander of the Joint Force on the evolving security situation in the Liptako-Gourma region emphasized the need for the Joint Force to have a good understanding of the phenomena and the links between violent extremism, transnational organised crime and local conflicts to ensure the efficiency of operations. Discussions also focused on the challenges facing the Joint Force in link with human rights respect. 2) Within the framework of collaboration between the ISS and the G5 Sahel Defense College , the team was invited to present research findings to cadets of the 2nd promotion of the G5 Sahel Defence College on the following themes: violent extremism, transnational organized crime and local conflicts in the Liptako-Gourma; the logic of engagement and technical recruitment in violent extremist groups as well as on the responses of states and their implications for populations.

title.narrative: Advanced draft of a conflict analysis produced by trained and technically supported civil society women available

description.narrative: This is to verify whether or not the conflict analysis to be generated by women trained and supported by ISS will indeed be delivered, demonstrating effective use of the knowledge and skills acquired trough ISS training and support

comment.narrative: The actual will have to be informed as YES or NO, depending on whether or not an advanced draft of the conflict analysis generated by trained and supported civil society women is available by end of 2021 (even if the publucation process goes into early 2022)

In December, ISS organized a participatory conflict analysis workshop. During the first two days of the workshop, participating women presented a preliminary analysis of the security situation in their respective communes (Abala, Ayorou, Banibangou, Bankilaré, Ouallam) based on a template that was shared with them prior to the workshop. Their presentations provided the substantive basis for the conflict analysis of the security situation in the Tillaberi region from community women’s perspective. At the end of the 5-day workshop, the ISS, WANEP Niger and the 10 participants were able to collect primary data and draft an outline for the conflict analysis. The 10 local civil society women will continue to collect data in the field. The first draft of the conflict analysis is expected in March 2022.

The actual will have to be informed as YES or NO, depending on wheter or not an advanced draft of the conflict analysis generated by trained and supported civil society women is available by end of 2021 (even if the publucation process goes into early 2022)
The data collection will start in November 2021, leading to report writing by December 2021.

The actual will have to be informed as YES or NO, depending on wheter or not an advanced draft of the conflict analysis generated by trained and supported civil society women is available by end of 2021 (even if the publucation process goes into early 2022)
The data collection will start in septembre 2021, leading to report writing by November 2021.

title.narrative: Resilience: Navigating livelihood in the shadows of Boko Haram Output: Research findings made available to stakeholders throung dissemination activities

description.narrative: This are the dissemination acitivities such as briefings, media interviews, invitations to present/moderate webinars and seminars.

title.narrative: Number of dissemination activities

description.narrative: This is the number of policy briefings, media interviews, presentation at seminars/workshops/webinars to disseminate ISS research findings ion the challenges facing Lake Chad basin

comment.narrative: The ISS has given several media interviews with local and international media that have been informed by data collected from the resilience study. Media organisations include AFP, The New Arab, Le Monde and Forbes Israel. The ISS has also been invited to contribute to a number of seminars and workshops hosted by African Economic Congress, the Lake Chad Basin Governors' Forum and UN-CTED. Presentations at these platforms drew on the trends of resilience and the unfolding security situation in the region, along with its implications for communities’ livelihood.

The ISS has given several media interviews with local and international media that have been informed by data collected from the resilience study. Media organisations include the BBC World Service, AFP, West African Democratic Radio, Channel Africa Radio, CGTN Africa, German News Agency. The ISS has also been invited to participate in a number of seminars and workshops hosted by organisations such as Chatham House, African Center for Strategic Studies, UNDP, UNCTED. All those presentations were drawn on the unfolding security situation in the region and its implications for communities’ livelihood. Through these engagements, the ISS has met the target for this quarter.

The ISS has given several media interviews with local and international media that have been informed by data collected from the resilience study. Media organisations include the BBC World Service, RFI, Le Monde, TVC Nigeria, West African Democratic Radio, Premium Times Nigeria, Tchad24 and France 24. The ISS has also been invited to participate in a number of seminars and workshops hosted by organisations such as Chatham House, Wilton Park, and the Humanitarian Policy Group. A presentation was also delivered UN Office for Human Rights on civilian protection, which drew heavily from the findings of the resilience study. Through these engagements, the ISS has met the target for this quarter.

comment.narrative: Data gathered from the resilience study have informed insights that have beeen shared with stakeholders at very high-level dialogues including the Lake Chad Basin Governors Forum, and a briefing event on the impact of evolving conflict dynamics on stabilisation. The ISS received very good feedback from stakeholders such as the Executive Secretary of the Lake Chad Basin Commission on the usefulness of the insights.

This result will be completed with the dissemination of the WAR on Resilience in the Shadows of Boko Haram. The report is at its final stage of revision-layout and should be ready for dissemination by March 2022.

comment.narrative: Briefings with Dutch and Swedish Embassies, as well as the British Foreign, Commonwealth adn Development Office were informed by the data collected from the resilience study, consequently influencing their programming. Data from the resilience study also contributed to a briefing with the UN Inter-Agency Task Force on ways of improving state presence in the Lake Chad Basin.

Briefings with the Irish Embassy, as well as presentations at several events organised by donors and stakeholders including UNOCA and Médecins Sans Frontières who were informed by the data collected from the resilience study. This contributed to shaping their programming. Data from the resilience study also contributed to a Situation Analysis Workshop of the UN Regional Stabilization Facility.

Data from the resilience study also contributed to the Second Roundtable on ISIL Trends and Developments in Africa, convened by CTED and in which ISS contributed. Additional stakeholders whose programmatic processes benefitted from ISS research included Meta (Facebook)

title.narrative: Number of national, regional and continental policy processes in which research findings have been used

description.narrative: This is the number of national, regional and continental policies process on which ISS research findings have been used. It also includes technical support provided by ISS based on research findings

comment.narrative: As part of its consultative visit in Abuja (Nigeria), ISS organised a seminar on the trends emerging from the activities of the Boko Haram factions (ISWAP and JAS) in the post-Shekau period and their implications for stabilisation in the Lake Chad Basin. This seminar was attended by around 50 national and international stakeholders. During the visit the ISS also briefed the Irish, Danish and Norwegian embassies, as well as the UK-CSSF on the unfording security dynamics in the Lake Chad Basin. The ISS team in Abuja also briefed the Swedish embassy there on Feedback received after the seminar and the briefing confirmed that key stakeholders had gained an up-to-date knowledge of the Boko Haram situation and the implications for stabilisation.

title.narrative: Number of national, regional and continental policies process in which research findings have been used

description.narrative: This is the number of national, regional and continental policies process on which ISS research findings have been used. It is also include technical support provided by ISS based on research findings

comment.narrative: A briefing delivered to the African Union's Special Envoy to Chad gave the ISS an opportunity for influencing continental programming with insights from the resilience study. Also, following a presentation by the ISS that drew on data from the resilience study at a side event on SPRRR in the LCB during the UN's 2021 CT Week, the Executive Secretary of the Lake Chad Basin Commission expressed his gratitude to the ISS for providing insights that help shape their programming at the Commission.

As part of a bi-monthly briefing to the UNDP, ISS presented an analysis of trends emerging from the activities of the Boko Haram factions (ISWAP and JAS) in the post-Shekau period and their implications for stabilisations in the Lake Chad Basin. Along with the analysis were policy recommendations for addressing governance and developmental needs and improving civil protection and livelihoods, among others. The briefing was attended by about 100 persons, including representatives from the various UN agencies, the EU, the French Development Agency and embassies. Feedback received after the briefing confirmed that key stakeholders had gained an up-to-date knowledge of the Boko Haram situation and the implications for stabilisation.

description.narrative: This result seeks to verify that ISS research leads to the provision of empirical knowledge and evidence-based policy recommendations to national and international actors on human security and conflict econmy implications of gold mining in Western Mali.

title.narrative: Aggregated number of publications, policy briefings, media interviews and expert contributions to ISS and external events delivered, which adress issues raised by the research findings

description.narrative: These are direct research outputs (composed of: publications, policy briefings and media interviews) adressing issues raised by the research findings on Western Mali's gold-mining

comment.narrative: By the end of 2021, ISS intends to have delivered at least 12 research outputs informed by the findings of the research and analytical work on the issue of human security threatens associated to gold mining in Mali. These outputs may include any combination of publications, policy briefings, media interviews and expert contributions to ISS and external events delivered, which address the issue of human security implication of gold mining in Mali.

A brifefing was delivered to the Embassy of the Kingdom of Netherlands. ISS also published 2 ISS Today on the research findings and the primary results of the research were shared with key actors during a workshop organised by the institution.

By the end of 2021, ISS intends to have delivered at least 12 research outputs informed by the findings of the research and analytical work on the issue of human security threatens associated to gold mining in Mali. These outputs may include any combination of publications, policy briefings, media interviews and expert contributions to ISS and external events delivered, which address the issue of human security implication of gold mining in Mali.

On 4th October 2021, ISS organized a consultative workshop on human security threat associated with gold mining in Kayes region in the Prefecture of Kéniéba. The success of the workshop led to two other consultative workshops in December in Kayes and in Bamako where ISS was invited by miners to share with them the findings of its research. On 11th of November, ISS delivered an interview on BBC on artisanal gold mining ban by the Malian State. At the invitation of Mali’s Ministry of Mines, ISS participated in the Forum on the degradation of Mali's waterways by gold mining on 17th November. ISS published on 9th December an ISS Today on the impacts of artisanal gold mining on women in Mali and Senegal.

By the end of 2021, ISS intends to have delivered at least 12 research outputs informed by the findings of the research and analytical work on the issue of human security threatens associated to gold mining in Mali. These outputs may include any combination of publications, policy briefings, media interviews and expert contributions to ISS and external events delivered, which address the issue of human security implication of gold mining in Mali.
On the 13th of September, an interview was made for the journal Liberation.
